xxl.core.cursors.wrappers
Class QueueCursor<E>

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.cursors.AbstractCursor<E>
      xxl.core.cursors.wrappers.QueueCursor<E>
Type Parameters:
E - the type of the elements returned by this iteration.
All Implemented Interfaces:
Iterator<E>, Cursor<E>
public class QueueCursor<E>
extends AbstractCursor<E>

A queue-cursor wraps a queue to a cursor, i.e., the wrapped queue can be accessed via the cursor interface. All method calls are passed to the underlying queue. Therefore the methods remove, update and reset throw an UnsupportedOperationException.

See Also:
Iterator, Cursor, AbstractCursor, Queue

Method Detail

open

public void open()
Opens the queue-cursor, i.e., signals it to reserve resources, open the underlying queue, etc. Before a cursor has been opened calls to methods like next or peek are not guaranteed to yield proper results. Therefore open must be called before a cursor's data can be processed. Multiple calls to open do not have any effect, i.e., if open was called the cursor remains in the state opened until its close method is called.

Note, that a call to the open method of a closed cursor usually does not open it again because of the fact that its state generally cannot be restored when resources are released respectively files are closed.

Specified by:
open in interface Cursor<E>
Overrides:
open in class AbstractCursor<E>

close

public void close()
Closes the queue-cursor, i.e., signals it to clean up resources, close the underlying queue, etc. When a cursor has been closed calls to methods like next or peek are not guaranteed to yield proper results. Multiple calls to close do not have any effect, i.e., if close was called the cursor remains in the state closed.

Note, that a closed cursor usually cannot be opened again because of the fact that its state generally cannot be restored when resources are released respectively files are closed.

Specified by:
close in interface Cursor<E>
Overrides:
close in class AbstractCursor<E>

hasNextObject

protected boolean hasNextObject()
Returns true if the iteration has more elements. (In other words, returns true if next or peek would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)

Specified by:
hasNextObject in class AbstractCursor<E>
Returns:
true if the queue-cursor has more elements.

nextObject

protected E nextObject()
Returns the next element in the iteration. This element will be accessible by some of the queue-cursor's methods, e.g., update or remove, until a call to next or peek occurs. This is calling next or peek proceeds the iteration and therefore its previous element will not be accessible any more.

Specified by:
nextObject in class AbstractCursor<E>
Returns:
the next element in the iteration.
Throws:
ConcurrentModificationException - If the element returned by peek would differ from that returned by a call to next.

size

public int size()
Returns the number of elements in this queue-cursor. If this queue-cursor contains more than Integer.MAX_VALUE elements, returns Integer.MAX_VALUE.

Returns:
the number of elements in this queue-cursor.

getQueue

public Queue<? extends E> getQueue()
Returns the wrapped queue. Use with care: modifications to the wrapped queue can have undesired effects.

Returns:
the queue wrapped by this QueueCursor.
Since:
1.1
